comments: This course covers the methodologies and techniques important to designing large complex, purposeful systems and to discovering policies that influence them throughout the stages of their lifecycle. Specifically, the student learns systems theory, systems methodologies, bottom up modeling, and how to further research and apply the synthetic paradigm.   Students generally felt that this course was lacking in cohesive content, with many stating they “learned absolutely nothing.” One student reported that the course was “poorly organized,” and students felt that the material was being made up “along the way.” Multiple students agreed that it was “undoubtedly the worst course I have ever taken.”   Students remarked that the Professor Silverman seemed more interested in “speaking of his own projects” than in teaching the material. Students regarded the professor as “unimpressive,” “passive aggressive,” and “incredibly incompetent.” Professor Silverman’s communication skills were described as “poor” and his teaching abilities as “utterly lacking.”   Students generally found this course to be mildly difficult. Many would not recommend this course to either a major or non-major.   This review is based on the 7 student comments which were submitted.
